document.id: Lac Courte Oreilles Tribal Governing Board Res. No. 2025-32
document.heading: Approval and Codification of the Individual Assistance Donations Program of the Lac Courte Oreilles Band of Lake Superior Chippewa Indians

recital.text: the Lac Courte Oreilles Band of Lake Superior Chippewa Indians is a federally recognized Indian tribe ("Tribe") organized pursuant to the provisions of the Indian Reorganization Act of 1934, 25 U.S.C. §5101, et seq.; and,

the Tribal Governing Board serves as the governing body of Lac Courte Oreilles Band of Lake Superior Chippewa Indians pursuant to Article III, § 1 of the Amended Constitution and Bylaws of the Lac Courte Oreilles Band of Lake Superior Chippewa Indians; and

the Tribal Governing Board is empowered to "delegate to subordinate boards, officers, committees or cooperative associations which are open to all members of the Band any of the foregoing powers, reserving the right to review any action taken by virtue of such delegated powers," pursuant to Article V, §1(m); and

the Tribal Governing Board approved and codified the Lac Courte Oreilles Tribal Code of Law (LCOTCL) General Welfare Exclusion Ordinance on October 10, 2023 to support allowable tax exemptions that meet specific criteria for exemption from IRS Code Section 139E for eligible Tribal Members; and
the Tribal Governing Board has a long history of providing critical benefits to Tribal Members, and this financial benefit is fundamental to the sovereignty and cultural integrity of the Tribe; and
the Tribe is in the best position to determine the needs of its members and provide for the general welfare of tribal citizens and tribal communities; and

the Tribe has established this Individual Assistance Donations Program to meet the requirements of the General Test as defined the Tribe's General Welfare Exclusion Law, the General Criteria as defined in I.R.S. Rev. Proc. 2014-35, Sec. 5, and the requirements of the Tribal General Welfare Exclusion Act of 2014, 26 U.S.C §139E(b).

that the Tribal Governing Board hereby adopts and codifies the Individual Assistance Donations Program Ordinance as LCOTCL MCC.7 in order to establish a Program to assist in providing financial assistance to members of the Lac Courte Oreilles Band.

recital.conjunction: NOW THEREFORE BE IT FINALLY RESOLVED,
recital.text: as follows: Tribal Governing Board adopts and codifies the attached Chapter MCC.7 Individual Assistance Donations Program of the Lac Courte Oreilles Band of Lake Superior Chippewa Indians.

procedural-data.text: I, the undersigned, as Secretary/Treasurer of the Lac Courte Oreilles Tribal Governing Board, hereby certify that the Tribal Governing Board is composed of seven (7) members, of whom 7 being present, constituted a quorum on this 3rd day of February, 2025, that the foregoing Resolution was duly adopted at said meeting by an affirmative vote of 6 members, 0 against, 0 abstaining, and that said Resolution is a lawful act of the Tribe.
Lac Courte Oreilles Tribal Governing Board

container.heading: Individual Assistance Donations Program of the Lac Courte Oreilles Band of Lake Superior Chippewa Indians
container.text: This ordinance is enacted pursuant to the inherent sovereign authority of the Lac Courte Oreilles Band of Lake Superior Chippewa Indians which predates its Treaties of 1825, 1826, 1837, 1842, 1847 and 1854 with the United States Government for the purpose of the implementation of this inherent sovereign authority, Article V, § 1 (m) and (s) of the Amended Constitution and Bylaws of the Lac Courte Oreilles Band of Lake Superior Chippewa Indians, empowers the Tribal Governing Board to: "delegate to subordinate boards, officers, committees or cooperative associations which are open to all members of the Band any of the foregoing powers, reserving the right to review any action taken by virtue of such delegated powers," Article V, § 1 (m).

section.heading: Title
section.text: This ordinance shall be known as the Individual Assistance Donations Code of the Lac Courte Oreilles Band of Lake Superior Chippewa Indians.

section.heading: Authority
section.text: This ordinance is enacted pursuant to the inherent sovereign authority of the Lac Courte Oreilles Band of Lake Superior Chippewa Indians. In the implementation of this inherent sovereign authority, Article V, § 1 (m) and (s) of the Amended Constitution and Bylaws of the Lac Courte Oreilles Band of Lake Superior Chippewa Indians, empowers the Tribal Governing Board to: "delegate to subordinate boards, officers, committees or cooperative associations which are open to all members of the Band any of the foregoing powers, reserving the right to review any action taken by virtue of such delegated powers," Article V, § 1 (m)

para.text: The purpose of this ordinance is to provide the formal process by which a Tribal Member may receive a donation from the Tribe.

This ordinance defines the duties and responsibilities of Individual Assistance Donations Committee, Lac Courte Oreilles Tribal Governing Board, Lac Courte Oreilles Accounting Department, and other persons involved in the granting or denial of Donations.

section.heading: Establishment
section.text: The Individual Assistance Donations Program is hereby established as an approved program of the Tribe in accordance with the Tribe's General Welfare Exclusion law. The purpose of the Donations Program is to provide financial assistance to members of the Tribe to address the general welfare needs of members.

section.heading: General Welfare Exclusion
section.text: The Individual Assistance Donations Program meets the requirements of the General Test as defined in the Tribe's General Welfare Exclusion law. General Criteria as defined in I.R.S. Rev. Proc. 2014-35, Sec. 5, and the requirements of the Tribal General Welfare Exclusion Act of 2014, 26 U.S.C. § 139E(b). The assistance provided by the Individual Assistance Donations Program is:

para.text: Paid on behalf of the Tribe;
Pursuant to an approved Tribal Program;
Does not discriminate in favor of or against members of the Tribal Governing Board;
Available to any eligible member of the Tribe who meets the guidelines of the approved program;
Provided for the promotion of general welfare;
Not lavish or extravagant;
Not compensation for services; and
Not a per capita payment.

section.heading: Effective Date
section.text: Except as otherwise provided in specific sections, the provisions of this ordinance shall be effective on the date adopted by the Tribal Governing Board.

para.text: Shall be interpreted and applied as the minimum requirements applicable to the granting or denial of Donation requests made to the Tribal Governing Board and/or the Individual Assistance Donations Committee;
Shall be liberally construed in favor of the Tribe; and
Shall not be deemed a limitation or repeal of any other tribal power or authority.

section.heading: Severability and Non-Liability
section.text: If any section, provision or portion of this ordinance is adjudged unconstitutional or invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, the remainder of this ordinance shall not be affected thereby. The Tribe further asserts immunity on its part and that of its agencies, employees, and/or agents from any action or damages that may occur as a result of reliance upon and conformance with this ordinance.

section.heading: Repeal of Inconsistent Tribal Ordinances
section.text: All ordinances and resolutions inconsistent with this ordinance are hereby repealed. To the extent that this ordinance imposes greater restrictions than those contained in any other tribal law, code, ordinance or regulation, the provisions of this ordinance shall govern.

section.heading: General Definitions
section.text: Any term not defined in this section shall be given its ordinary meaning. The following terms, wherever used in this ordinance, shall be construed to apply as follows, except where the context indicates otherwise:

para.text: "Applicant" shall mean an individual who is applying for a Donation from the Tribe through the Donations Committee.
"Committee" shall mean the Donations Committee.
"Conditions" shall mean a requirement or prerequisite event or activity.
"Conflict of interest" shall mean a conflict between the private interests and the official responsibilities of the committee member.

"Individual Assistance Donation" shall mean benefits or payments under this approved program, which are paid to or on behalf of a recipient pursuant to this law. Donations provided under this approved program shall not be considered income of the recipient.

"Donation Committee" shall mean the three appointed tribal members who are tasked with reviewing completed requests for the Individual Assistance Donation Program and who are able to approve or deny such requests.

"Employee" shall mean any individual who is employed by the Tribe and is subject to the direction and control of the Tribe with respect to the material details of the work performed, or who has the status of an employee under the usual common law rules applicable to determining the employer-employee relationship. For the purposes of this ordinance, employee shall include individuals employed by a tribal entity or Tribally Chartered corporation.
"Family member" shall mean a spouse, child sibling, parent, grandparent, grandchild, step-parent, step-child, in-law or legal guardian.

"Hardship" shall mean a financial situation that prevents an individual from meeting a basic need because certain expenses arose as justified upon proof provided by the applicant and as defined in [Code Section].
"Individual" shall means an enrolled member of the Lac Courte Oreilles Band of Lake Superior Chippewa Indians.
"Recipient" shall mean any member entitled to receive assistance in accordance with this approved program.

"Reservation" or "Reservation Lands" means those lands located within the exterior boundaries of the Lac Courte Oreilles Reservation lands as well as off-reservation lands under the jurisdiction and purview of the Lac Courte Oreilles Tribe.
"Restriction" shall mean a limitation or constraint imposed.
"Tribe" shall mean the Lac Courte Oreilles Band of Lake Superior Chippewa Indians.

"Tribal Entity" shall mean a corporation or other organization which is wholly owned by the Lac Courte Oreilles Band of Lake Superior Chippewa Indians and is operated for governmental or commercial purposes.
"Tribal Governing Board" means the Tribal Governing Board of the Lac Courte Oreilles Band of Lake Superior Chippewa Indians.
"Tribal" or "Tribe" shall mean the Lac Courte Oreilles Band of Lake Superior Chippewa Indians, and includes all departments, divisions, business units, and other subdivisions of the Tribe.
"Tribal Member" means an individual who is an enrolled member of the Lac Courte Oreilles Band of Lake Superior Chippewa Indians.
A Committee is hereby created for the purpose of carrying out the provisions of this ordinance and shall have those powers as stated in this section.
Official Powers and Duties. The Committee shall carry out the following official powers and duties:
review and process applications for Donations in an orderly and efficiently manner;
Conduct regular meetings regarding budgets, requests, declinations, and other business related to donations;
provide formal, written reports on all donation decision including declinations to the Tribal Governing Board to approve or deny a Donation application that are necessary pursuant to tribal law; and
take other actions reasonably related to the purpose of the Committee.
Organization. The Committee shall be organized in accordance with the following guidelines;

The Donation Committee shall be composed of three (3) persons, all of whom must be members of the Tribe. Applications for appointment must meet the qualifications set forth in this ordinance. In no case shall a sitting Tribal Governing Board member be appointed as a Committee member. No individual Committee member, regardless of position, acting alone and without Committee approval is empowered or authorized to take any action or make any public statement regarding the Committee's positions on any matter. There shall be no limit on the number of terms any Committee member can serve, subject to any provision in the Tribal Constitution and Bylaws to the contrary.
The Tribal Governing Board shall recruit and post vacancies of the Committee to be filled from Tribal Membership. Applications shall be developed by the Tribal Governing Board.
Qualifications. Applicants for appointment to the Committee must satisfy the following requirements:
Be honest.
Have integrity.
Ability to withstand outside pressure to give gifts that do not meet the criteria for donation.
Be an enrolled Member of the Tribe.
Be at least 21 years of age.
Have no prior record of, or entry of a plea of no contest to, any of the following in any tribal, county, state or federal court, unless pardoned or forgiven:
A felony.
Fraud or misrepresentation in any connection.
Shall adhere to the care, loyalty, and conflict terms pursuant MCC.7.3.010(h)..
Term. The Tribal Governing Board may appoint applicants, who meet the qualifications established in Section MCC.7.3.010(d) above, to the Committee as follows:
The Tribal Governing Board shall appoint a replacement committee member for all vacancies to the Committee as soon as reasonably possible.

A member of the Committee may be removed by formal action of the Tribal Governing Board for neglect of duty, breach of confidentiality, conflict of interest, malfeasance in office, unexcused absences of more than three consecutive regular meetings, or other due cause in the Tribal Governing Board's sole discretion. The decision of the Tribal Governing Board regarding any such removal shall be final and not subject to appeal.

The Committee shall be appointed, and may be reappointed, by the Tribal Governing Board. Formal notification by the Tribal Governing Board as to the appointment or reappointment of any Committee member shall be conclusive evidence of the due and proper appointment.
Meetings.
Quorum. A majority of the full Committee shall constitute a quorum necessary to conduct Committee business, but no action shall be taken by a vote of less than a majority of such full Committee.

Voting. All Committee members are entitled to vote on all issues. At the call of the question, by any one member on a particular issue, voting shall take place thereon. Voting by proxy representation shall be prohibited.

Regularity of Meetings. Regular meetings of the Board shall be held weekly or at a time agreed upon by the Committee. Special meetings may be held at the discretion of the Chairperson or by request of three (3) Committee members.

Proceedings. All deliberations of the Committee are confidential. The Secretary shall keep complete and accurate records (minutes) of all meetings of the Committee. Minutes of all meetings shall be distributed to Committee members prior to the next meeting. Minutes shall be provided to the Tribal Governing Board upon adoption by the Committee.
Executive Sessions. The Committee must consider all matters in executive (closed to the public) sessions that is closed to the public and closed to any individual not on the Committee:
Review of applications submitted pursuant to this ordinance and the grant, or denial, of applications and request for individual assistance donations;
Conferring with the Office of the Attorney General who is rendering oral or written legal advice with respect to the Committee's responsibilities and duties;
Compensation of Committee Members.

Appointed members of the Committee shall receive a stipend of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per month while serving as a current committee member. The amount of stipend is subject to change by resolution of the Tribal Governing Board. A committee member must accept the compensation under this provision.
Restrictions.
No Committee member shall deliberate on an application involving a conflict of interest or the evaluation of family member requests.
Nothing in this ordinance authorizes the Committee to interfere with management, operations, and employment relations or decisions of the Tribe or Tribal entities.
Care, Loyalty, and Conflict.

Committee members shall discharge their duties in good faith and in a manner that the member reasonably believes is in the best interest of the Committee, and with due diligence that an ordinarily prudent person in a like position would exercise under similar circumstances. It is expected that all Committee members will work in a competent and professional manner that reflects favorably on the Tribal Governing Board and the Tribe.

Committee members shall, at all times, subordinate their personal interests to those of the Tribe and the Committee and shall avoid conflicts of interest, including without limitation, that no Committee members shall exploit information related to Tribe, the Committee, or an applicant for their own personal gain or profit.

No Committee member shall commit any act with respect to the Tribe, the Committee, or an applicant that is illegal, fraudulent, or willfully unfair to either the Tribe, the Committee, or an applicant.
In the event of a conflict of interest regarding an application for a Donation, the Individual Assistance Donation Committee member shall refrain from handling or discussing the application.
Personal Liability and Immunity.

To the fullest extent permitted by law, the Tribe shall indemnify members of the Committee against costs, expenses, and liabilities incurred by them in carrying out their official duties as members of the Committee.

The Committee, as a delegated body of the Tribal Governing Board pursuant to the Lac Court Oreilles Constitution, Article V, § 1 (m), is immune, as is the Tribe, from suit and legal process in any state, federal or tribal court as the Lac Court Oreilles Band of Lake Superior Chippewa Indians has not waived any aspect of its sovereign immunity in enacting this ordinance.

section.heading: Donation Application, Donation Program is program of last resort.

para.text: Eligibility. Any applicant and recipient of a donation may be required to demonstrate individual or family need. All applicants and recipients of a donation must comply with the following sections.

Must request other tribal assistance first. Individual Assistance Donations Program is a program of last resort. The Individual Assistance Donations Program is a program of last resort, meaning that all applicants must apply for, and be rejected from, another tribal program that handles assistance for the same matter or type of benefit requested. No assistance will be granted by the Individual Assistance Donations Committee unless the applicant has provided proof of rejection from another program. Proof of rejection means a physical document describing the assistance requested and shall contain the other tribal program's written denial for ineligibility or other reasons.
Prior to receiving a donation, all applicants shall first seek for, and be rejected from, a donation the following programs.
Energy Assistance Program for assistance with utilities payments.
General Assistance Program for assistance with cash benefits.
Income Maintenance/Child Care for childcare assistance.
Consolidated Tribal Government Program for assistance with work/job skills, utilities, rent, childcare assistance, shuttle tokens, food, clothing, and tools.
Native Employment Works (NEW) Program for assistance with work/job skills, cash benefits, shuttle tokens, and vehicle repairs/fees.
Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) for assistance with work/job skills and cash benefits.
LCO Elder Services Program for assistance with vehicle repairs and minor home repairs.
Vocational Rehabilitation Program for assistance with work/job skills, shuttle tokens, vehicle repairs fees, clothing, and tools.
Workforce Investment Act (WIOA) for assistance with work/job skills.
Food Distribution for assistance with food.
LCO Indian Child Welfare & Family Services for assistance with utilities, transportation, and clothing.
LCO Independent Living for work/job skills, utilities, rent, transportation, vehicle repairs/fees, clothing, and tools and teaching in independent living skills.
Kinship Program for assistance with work/job skills and cash benefits, and clothing (when funding allows).
LCO Health Center Medical Transportation for assistance with transportation, delivery of medications, and medical supplies.
PRC2, Payor of Last Resort Program for reimbursement and or payment for eligible medical expenses.
Or any other assistance program that the Tribe may develop in the future, from time to time.

Upon the required showing of proof of rejection or ineligibility from one of the above programs, the requested assistance must be the same type of assistance that was requested from the rejecting program.

Ineligibility. An individual is ineligible for Individual Assistance Donation if they have already received a Donation in the proceeding 12-month period and/or have reached the yearly donation limit of $1,000. Applicants are ineligible for a donation if they have not provided written proof of the denial of assistance from another tribal program.
Initiating an Application. Applications for assistance must be written and clearly stated on a form developed by the Tribal Governing Board.
Required Application Information. Each applicant is responsible for submitting all required materials and authorizations.
A completed Donation application shall include, at a minimum, the following:
Full legal name;
Date of Birth;
Street address, city, state, and zip code;
Phone number;
E-mail address;
Enrollment number and a copy of the applicant's Lac Courte Oreille enrollment card;
Employment status and wage information;
the applicant's records of prior donation requests, including denials;
the total amount requested;

a personal written statement or declaration from the applicant that a hardship exists, including the reason(s) for requesting a Donation, and that all information provided is accurate and in accordance with Tribal and federal law. The signature of the applicant, electronic or handwritten, is required to affirm the declaration; and
A written denial of assistance from another tribal program.
Incomplete Application Consequences. Failure of the applicant to provide a complete application, or any of the required information and/or materials may result in:
the application being returned with a request for more information; or
the application being removed from consideration; or
denial of a Donation.

Applicant Misrepresentation: If a Donation is granted and it is later determined that information was misrepresented or false, or pertinent information was purposefully omitted, the Tribal Governing Board shall have the right to rescind the Donation and direct the Office of the Attorney General to recover, through court action or wage garnishment, the amount of the Donation granted and any and all costs incurred by the donation request or the recovery thereof.
Falsifying a Donation Application: The Donations Committee reserves the right to deny any donation application that:
is used in conjunction with criminal conduct,
is fraudulently presented for illegitimate purpose(s), or
the committee has been purposefully misled about the use, or intended use, of a donation.

section.heading: Individual Gifting of Individual Assistance Donations by Tribal Governing Board Members Disallowed

para.text: Except as otherwise provided herein or by applicable rule or regulation adopted hereunder by the Tribe, or by other applicable law, no Elected Official shall authorize any monetary benefits to any tribal member or nontribal member, without the consensus approval (four signatures) of the Tribal Governing Board including but not limited to the following:
Rooms or other charges at the Lac Courte Oreilles Casino, Lodge and Convention Center.
Rooms or other charges at any hotel or motel wheresoever situated.
Gas or other charges at any Tribal gas station.
Any charges at the Landing.
Any other charges as otherwise established by the Tribal Governing Board.
The Budget for the Individual Assistance Donations Committee shall be allocated under the same procedure as the government tribal budget process.
The budget shall be approved by the Tribal Governing Board.
The Donations Committee shall not exceed the approved budget and any modification to the budget requires prior approval by a majority vote of the Tribal Governing Board.

All members of the Committee understand, acknowledge, and agree by virtue of service on the Committee that the performance of their duties and responsibilities and obligations under this ordinance shall occur mainly within the territory of the Tribe as set forth in Article I, § 1 of the Lac Courte Oreilles Tribal Constitution; that they have read and understand the duties and responsibilities, obligations, and all other provisions of this ordinance; and that they have agreed to abide by the same.
The Committee shall have access to confidential applicant information as established pursuant to this ordinance.

Any member of the Committee who releases any information without approval by a majority vote of the Tribal Governing Board, or uses any information for personal gain, that is part of an application shall be subject to sanctions, including dismissal from the Committee and penalties under Federal, State or Tribal law.
